tn.text: This is the next part of the story. Jesus begins to teach his disciples in front of thousands of people.
"While they were doing that"

tn.ref: when many thousands of the people ... they trampled on each other
tn.text: This is background information that tells the setting of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"a very great crowd"
This is an exaggeration in order to express how many people there were. AT: "they were stepping on each other" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: he began to say to his disciples first of all
tn.text: "Jesus first started speaking to his disciples, and said to them"

tn.ref: Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy
tn.text: Just as yeast spreads through a whole lump of bread dough, their hypocrisy was spreading through the whole community. AT: "Guard yourself against the hypocrisy of the Pharisees, which is like yeast" or "Be careful that you do not become hypocrites like the Pharisees. Their evil behavior influences everyone just as yeast affects a lump of dough" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "But" connects this verse to the previous verse about the hypocrisy of the Pharisees. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])

tn.ref: there is nothing concealed that will not be revealed
tn.text: "everything that is hidden will be shown." This can be stated in active form. AT: "people will find out about everything that people do secretly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: nothing hidden that will not be known
tn.text: This means the same thing as the first part of the sentence in order to emphasize its truth. It can also be stated in active form. AT: "people will learn about everything that others try to hide" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: will be heard in the light
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "people will hear in the light" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "whispered to another person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"in a closed room." This refers to private speech. AT: "in privacy" or "secretly"
"will be shouted loudly." This can be stated in active form. AT: "people will proclaim" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Houses in Israel had flat roofs, so people could go up and stand on top of them. If readers would be distracted trying to imagine how people would get up on the house tops, this could also be translated with a more general expression, such as "from a high place where everyone will be able to hear."

tn.ref: I say to you my friends
tn.text: Jesus readdresses his disciples to mark a shift in his speech to a new topic, in this case, to speak about not being afraid.

tn.ref: they have no more that they can do
tn.text: "they cannot cause any more harm" or "they cannot hurt you anymore"
The phrase "the one" refers to God. This could be stated. AT: "Fear God who" or "Fear God, because" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"after he kills you" or "after he kills someone"

tn.ref: has authority to throw you into hell
tn.text: This is a general statement about God's authority to judge people. It does not mean this will happen to the disciples. AT: "has authority to throw people into hell"

tn.ref: Are not five sparrows sold for two small coins?
tn.text: Jesus uses a question to teach the disciples. AT: "You know that five sparrows are sold for only two small coins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
very small, seed-eating birds

tn.ref: not one of them is forgotten in the sight of God
tn.text: This could be stated in active form and in positive form. AT: "God never forgets any of them" (UDB) or "God indeed remembers every sparrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: even the hairs of your head are all numbered
tn.text: This could be stated in active form. AT: "God knows even how many hairs are on your head" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The reason for the fear is not stated. Possible meanings are 1) "Do not be afraid of what will happen to you" or 2) "So do not be afraid of people who could hurt you."

tn.ref: You are more valuable than many sparrows
tn.text: "You are worth more to God than many sparrows"
Jesus readdresses his audience to mark a shift in his speech to a new topic, in this case, to speak about confession.

tn.ref: everyone who confesses me before men
tn.text: What is confessed can be stated clearly. AT: "whoever tells others that he is my disciple" or "anyone who acknowledges before others that he is loyal to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Jesus was referring to himself. AT: "I, the Son of Man"

tn.ref: he who denies me before men
tn.text: "he who disowns me before people." What is denied can be stated clearly. AT: "whoever refuses to acknowledge to others that he is my disciple" or "if anyone refuses to say that he is loyal to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"will be disowned." This can be stated in active form. AT: "the Son of Man will deny him " or "I will deny that he is my disciple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Everyone who speaks a word against the Son of Man
tn.text: "Everyone who says something bad about the Son of Man"
"he will be forgiven." This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will forgive him for that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"speaks evil against the Holy Spirit"

This can be expressed with an active verb. AT: "God will not forgive him." When someone does not forgive someone, it means that he considers him guilty. AT: "God will consider him guilty forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
It is not stated who brings them into judgment.
"into the synagogues to question you before the religious leaders" (UDB)
It may be necessary to combine these into one statement. AT: "other people who have power in the country" (UDB)
"at that time" or "then"
This is a break in Jesus' teachings. A man asks Jesus to do something and Jesus responds to him.
Inheritances came from the father in that culture. This could be stated. AT: "share my father's property with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Possible meanings are 1) this is simply a way to address a stranger or 2) Jesus is rebuking the man. Your language might have a way of addressing people in either of these ways. Some people do not translate this word at all.

tn.ref: who made me a judge or a mediator over you?
tn.text: Jesus uses a question to rebuke the man. AT: "I am not your judge or mediator." Some languages would use the plural form for "you" or "your" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion|Rhetorical Question]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you|Forms of You]])
The word "them" here probably refers to the whole crowd of people. AT: "And Jesus said to the crowd"

tn.ref: keep yourselves from all greedy desires
tn.text: "guard yourself from every form of greed." AT: "do not allow yourself to love having things" or "do not let the urge to have more things control you"
This is a general statement of fact. It does not refer to any specific person. Some languages have a way of expressing that.
"how many things he owns" (UDB) or "how much wealth he has"
Jesus continues his teaching by telling a parable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])
Jesus was probably still speaking to the entire crowd.
"grew a very good harvest"

tn.ref: What will I do, because I do not have a place to store my crops?
tn.text: This question reflects what the man was thinking to himself. AT: "I do not know what to do, because I do not have any place big enough to store all my crops!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
buildings where farmers store the crops and food that they grow after it is harvested
"possessions"

tn.ref: I will say to my soul
tn.text: "I will say to myself" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The man is speaking to himself. AT: "I have"
Jesus quotes how God responds to the rich man, as he finishes telling his parable.

tn.ref: tonight your soul is required of you
tn.text: The "soul" refers to the life of a person. AT: "you will die tonight" or "I will take your life from you tonight" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the things you have prepared, whose will they be?
tn.text: "who will own what you have stored up?" or "who will have what you prepared?" God uses a question to make the man realize that he would no longer possess those things. AT: "the things that you have prepared will belong to someone else!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"saves up valuable things"
"poor"
The meaning is that this person has not been concerned with the things that are important to God, or that God will reward. AT: "in the view of God" or "in relation to God"
Jesus continues teaching his disciples in front of the crowd.
"For that reason" or "Because of what this story teaches"
"I want to tell you something important" or "you need to listen carefully to this"

tn.ref: about your life—what you will eat
tn.text: "about your life and what you will eat" or "about having enough food in order to live"

tn.ref: about your body—what you will wear
tn.text: "about your body and what you will wear" or "about having enough clothes to put on your body"

tn.ref: For life is more than food
tn.text: This is a general statement of value. AT: "life is more important than the food you eat" (UDB)

tn.ref: the body is more than clothes
tn.text: This is a general statement of value. AT: "your body is more important than the clothes you put on it" (UDB)

This refers either to 1) crows, a kind of bird that eats mostly grain, or 2) ravens, a kind of bird that eats the flesh of dead animals. Jesus' audience would have considered the ravens worthless since the Jewish people could not eat these types of birds.
These are places where food is stored.

tn.ref: How much more valuable you are than the birds!
tn.text: This is an exclamation, not a question. Jesus emphasizes the fact that people are much more valuable to God then birds. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])
Jesus uses a question to teach his disciples. AT: "None of you can make your life any longer by being anxious!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: add a cubit to his lifespan
tn.text: This is a metaphor because a cubit is a measure of length, rather than of time. The image is of a person's life stretched out as if it were a board, a rope, or some other physical object. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: If then you are not able ... the rest?
tn.text: Jesus uses another question to teach his disciples. AT: "Since you cannot do even this small thing, you should not worry about the other things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"Think about how the lilies grow"

Lilies are beautiful flowers that grow wild in the fields. If your language does not have a word for lily, you can use the name of another flower like that or translate it as "flowers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

The process of making thread or yard for cloth is called "spinning." It may be helpful to make this explicit. AT: "neither do they make thread in order to make cloth" or "and they do not make yarn" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Solomon who had great wealth" or "Solomon who wore beautiful clothes"

tn.ref: If God so clothes the grass in the field
tn.text: "If God clothes the grass in the field like that" or "If God gives the grass in the field such beautiful clothing." AT: "If God makes the grass in the field beautiful like this" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone throws it into a fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: how much more will he clothe you
tn.text: This is an exclamation, not a question. Jesus emphasizes that he will certainly take care of people even better than he does the grass. This could be stated clearly. AT: "he will certainly clothe you even better" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])

tn.ref: Do not look for what you will eat and what you will drink
tn.text: "Do not focus on what you will eat and drink" or "Do not greatly desire more to eat and drink"

tn.ref: all the nations of the world
tn.text: Here "nations" refers to "unbelievers." AT: "all people of other nations" or "all the unbelievers in the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
"focus on God's kingdom" or "greatly desire God's kingdom"

tn.ref: these things will be added to you
tn.text: "these things also will be given to you." "These things" refers to food and clothing. This could be stated in active form. AT: "God will give you these things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

Jesus was calling his disciples a flock. A flock is a group of sheep or goats that a shepherd cares for. As a shepherd cares for his sheep, God would care for Jesus' disciples. AT: "small group" or "dear group" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
It may be helpful to state what they receive. AT: "give to poor people the money you earn from the sales" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: Make for yourselves purses ... treasure in the heavens
tn.text: The purses and treasure in the heavens are the same thing. They both represent God's blessing in heaven. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is the result of giving to the poor. AT: "In this way you will make for yourselves"

tn.ref: purses which will not wear out
tn.text: "money bags that will not get holes in them"
"does not diminish" or "does not become less"
"thieves do not come near"
"moths do not destroy"
A "moth" is a small insect that eats holes in fabric. You may need to use a different insect, such as ants or termites.

tn.ref: where your treasure is, there your heart will be also
tn.text: "your heart will be focused on where you store your treasure"
Here "heart" refers to a person's thoughts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jesus begins to tell a parable. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

tn.ref: Let your long clothing be tucked in at your belt
tn.text: People wore long flowing robes. They would tuck them into their belt to keep the robes out of the way while they worked. AT: "Tuck your clothing into your belt so you are ready to serve" or "Be dressed and ready to serve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: let your lamps be kept burning
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "keep your lamps burning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: be like people looking for their master
tn.text: This compares the disciples being ready for Jesus to return to servants who are ready for their master to return. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
"returns home from a marriage feast"
This refers to the door of the master's house. It was the responsibility of his servants to open it for him.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"How good it is for"

tn.ref: whom the master will find watching when he comes
tn.text: "whose master finds them waiting for him when he returns" or "who are ready when the master returns"

tn.ref: he will tuck in his long clothing at his belt, and have them sit down
tn.text: Because the servants have been faithful and ready to serve their master, the master will now reward them by serving them.

tn.ref: in the second watch of the night
tn.text: The second watch was between 9:00 p.m. and midnight. AT: "late at night" or "just before midnight"

tn.ref: or if even in the third watch
tn.text: The third watch was from midnight to 3:00 a.m. AT: "or if he comes very late at night"
"In addition, also know" or "But you must also remember" (UDB)
"had known when"

tn.ref: he would not have let his house be broken into
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "he would not have let the thief break into his house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: because you do not know the hour when the Son of Man comes
tn.text: The only similarity between a thief and the Son of Man is that people do not know when either one will come, so they need to be ready.

tn.ref: do not know the hour when
tn.text: "do not know at what time"

tn.ref: when the Son of Man comes
tn.text: Jesus was talking about himself. AT: "when I, the Son of Man, will come"
In verse 42, Jesus begins to tell another parable.
In verse 41, there is a break in the storyline as Peter asks Jesus a question about the previous parable.

Jesus uses a question to answer Peter's question indirectly. He expected those who wanted to be faithful managers to understand that the parable was about them. AT: "I said it for everyone who is ... right time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Jesus tells another parable about how servants should be faithful while they wait for their master to return. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

tn.ref: whom his lord will set over his other servants
tn.text: "whom his lord puts in charge of his other servants"
"How good it is for that servant"

tn.ref: whom his lord finds doing that when he comes
tn.text: "if his lord finds him doing that work when he comes back"
This expression means they should pay special attention to what he is about to say.

tn.ref: will set him over all his property
tn.text: "will put him in charge of all his property"
This refers to the servant whose lord has put him in charge of the other servants.
"heart" here refers to the person. AT: "thinks to himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"My master will not return soon"
The words that are translated here as "male and female servants" are normally translated as "boys" and "girls." They may indicate that the servants were young or that they were dear to their master.

tn.ref: in a day when he does not expect
tn.text: "when the servant is not expecting him"

tn.ref: in an hour that he does not know
tn.text: "at an hour when he is not expecting him"

tn.ref: cut him in pieces and appoint a place for him with the unfaithful
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) this is a hyperbole for the master dealing out harsh punishment toward the slave, or 2) this describes the manner in which the servant will be executed and buried as punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Jesus finishes telling the parable.
"what his master wanted him to do"

tn.ref: will be beaten with many blows
tn.text: "will be hit many times" or "will be whipped many times." This can be stated in active form. AT: "his master will hit him many times" or "his master will punish him severely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Both servants are punished, but these phrases show the servant who intentionally disobeyed his master was punished more severely than the other servant.

tn.ref: But everyone who has been given much, from them much will be required
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "They will require more of anyone who has received much" or "The master will require more of everyone he has given much to" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the one ... much, even more will be asked
tn.text: This can be stated in active form.  AT: "the master will ask even more of the one ... much" or "the master will require even more of the one ... much" "  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the one who has been entrusted with much
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the one to whom the master has given much property to take care of" or "the one to whom the master has given much responsibility" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus continues to teach his disciples.

tn.ref: I came to cast fire upon the earth
tn.text: "I came to throw fire on the earth" or "I came to set the earth on fire." Possible meanings are 1) Jesus has come to judge people or 2) Jesus has come to purify believers or 3) Jesus has come to cause division among people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: how I wish that it were already kindled
tn.text: This exclamation emphasizes how much he wants this to happen. AT: "I wish very much that it was already lit" or "how I wish that it had already begun" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])

tn.ref: But I have a baptism to be baptized with
tn.text: Here "baptism" refers to what Jesus must suffer. Just as water covers a person during baptism, suffering will overwhelm Jesus. AT: "I must go through a baptism of terrible suffering" (UDB) or "I must be overwhelmed by suffering as a person being baptized is covered by water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "but" is used to show that he cannot cast the fire on the earth until after he goes through his baptism.

tn.ref: how I am distressed until it is completed
tn.text: This exclamation emphasizes how distressed he was. AT: "I am terribly distressed and will be so until I complete this baptism of suffering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])

tn.ref: Do you think that I came to bring peace on the earth?
tn.text: People expected the Messiah to bring them peace from their enemies. Jesus is not going to do that now. AT: "You should not think that I have come to bring peace on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"but I came to bring division" or "people will divide from each other because I have come"
"hostility" or "discord"

tn.ref: there will be five in one house divided
tn.text: This is an example of the kind of division there will be even within families.

tn.ref: there will be five in one house
tn.text: It may be helpful to state that this refers to people. AT: "there will be five people in one house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"will oppose" (UDB). It may be helpful to use a longer phrase for each of these occurrences. AT: "will be divided against" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Jesus begins to speak to the crowd.

tn.ref: When you see a cloud rising ... happens
tn.text: This condition normally meant rain was coming in Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Rain is coming" or "It is going to rain" (UDB)

tn.ref: when a south wind is blowing ... it happens
tn.text: This condition normally meant hot weather was coming in Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the earth and the sky"

tn.ref: how is it that you do not know how to interpret the present time?
tn.text: Jesus uses a question to rebuke the crowd. Jesus uses this question to convict them. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "you should know how to interpret the present time" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Why do you not judge what is right for yourselves
tn.text: Jesus uses a question to rebuke the crowd. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "You yourselves should discern what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"on your own initiative"

tn.ref: For when you go ... bit of money
tn.text: Jesus uses a hypothetical situation to teach the crowd. His point is that they should resolve the things they are able to resolve without involving the public courts. This can be restated to make it clear it might not happen. AT: "For if you were to go ... bit of money" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

Though Jesus is talking to a crowd, the situation he is presenting is something that a person would go through alone. So in some languages the word "you" would be singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"settle the matter with your adversary"
This refers to the magistrate, but the term here is more specific and threatening.
"does not hand you over"

tn.ref: the very last bit of money
tn.text: "the entire amount of money that your adversary demands"
